advice: Give ORS solution slowly with a spoon until the child is no longer thirsty.

Return immediately if the child becomes sicker or has blood in stool.

advice: Return for a follow-up visit in 3 days, or sooner if the child becomes sicker.
Refer the child if the child is not improving.
Cough with fast breathing is a sign of pneumonia. If there is no chest indrawing or other danger sign, you can treat the child with an antibiotic (amoxicillin).

For a child who is not exclusively breastfed, sipping a safe, soothing remedy—like honey in warm (not hot) water—can help relieve a cough and soothe the throat. There is no need for other medicine. Tell the caregiver that cough medicines may contain harmful ingredients, and they are expensive.
Ask to see the child with cough again in 3 days for a follow-up visit.
Bring the child right away if the child cannot drink or eat or is getting sicker. Especially watch for any difficult breathing.
Especially watch for any difficult breathing and bring the child right away.
Counsel caregiver on feeding or refer the child with yellow on the strap for supplemental feeding if there is a community-based feeding programme.

advice: Give frequent small sips of ORS solution from a cup or spoon. For a young child, use a spoon.
Offer as much ORS solution as the child will take, or at least 1/2 cup after each loose stool.
Continue usual fluids such as breast milk; if not exclusively breastfed, offer clean water.
Do not give very sweet drinks and juices.
If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes, then restart ORS solution more slowly.
If the dehydrated child drinks eagerly and continues to want ORS solution, continue giving ORS in front of you.
If the child becomes more alert and refuses ORS and is no longer thirsty, the child is ready to go home.
Put extra ORS solution in a covered container for the trip.

advice: Ask the caregiver to give the first dose immediately: 2 tablets.

Help the caregiver give the first dose right away.
Use a spoon to crush the tablet in a cup or small bowl.
Mix it with breast milk or with water, or crush it with banana or another favourite food.
Give the solution with a spoon and ensure the whole dose is taken.
Remind caregiver to give the second dose after 8 hours to avoid giving it too soon or waiting until the next day.

advice: For ALL children treated at home: advise on home care
Breastfeed more frequently during illness including diarrhoea
Increase the frequency of breastfeeding and breastfeed for longer at each feed
Breastfeeding also provides comfort to your sick baby
If your baby refuses to breastfeed, encourage your baby until he or she takes the breast again
If the baby is too weak to suckle, express breast milk to give the baby
This will also help you to keep up your milk supply and prevent breast difficulties
Give only breast milk and medicines recommended by your doctor/ health care provider
Do not give any throat or cough remedy
A child, even with a sore throat, will usually take the breast when offered
When you are sick, you can continue to breastfeed your baby. You may need extra fluids and support during this time yourself
For children who are not exclusively breastfed, give clean water and more fluid foods. Soup, rice water, and yoghurt drinks will help to replace the lost fluid during illness
The child with diarrhoea should also take ORS solution

notes: Page presents vignette-style prompts with pre-referral options; explicit thresholds only encoded when stated (e.g., 14 days, blood in stool, chest indrawing, unusually sleepy or unconscious, diarrhoea for 3 weeks).
Actions marked if_available=false where the page does not explicitly indicate to give; true where pre-referral treatment options are explicitly listed but require availability and clinical judgement.

variables.name: weather_cold
variables.prompt: Is the weather cold?

advice: If the child can drink and feed, advise the caregiver to continue to offer fluids and food to the child on the way to the health facility.
If the child is still breastfeeding, advise the mother to continue breastfeeding. Offer the breast more frequently and for a longer time at each feed.
If the child is not breastfeeding, advise the caregiver to offer water to drink and some easy -toeat food.
If the child has diarrhoea, help the caregiver start giving ORS solution right away. Sometimes the ORS solution can help the child stop vomiting. Then the child can take other oral medicines.
To keep the child warm, cover the child, including the child’s head, hands, and feet with a blanket. Keep the child dry if it rains.
If the weather is cold, advise the caregiver to put a cap on the child’s head and hold the child close to her body.

If the child is hot with fever, covering the body too much will raise the body temperature. It may make the child sicker and increase the danger of convulsions. A light cloth or blanket may be enough to cover the child with fever if the weather is warm. If the body becomes very hot, advise the caregiver to remove even the light blanket.

Offer more fluids and continue feeding; offer more food as the child gets better

Continue to support the family and help them give appropriate home care
